articles.title: ‘Human rights cannot wait’: Türk launches $400 million appeal for 2026
articles.summary: UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Volker Türk launched a $400 million appeal on Thursday in Geneva, as his office (OHCHR) continues to operate “in survival mode”.
articles.content:
He warned Member States that with crises mounting, the world cannot afford a human rights system in crisis.

“The cost of our work is low; the human cost of underinvestment is immeasurable,” he said.

“In times of conflict and in times of peace, we are a lifeline for the abused, a megaphone for the silenced, a steadfast ally to those who risk everything to defend the rights of others.”

Tweet URL

Documenting violations, supporting survivors

Last year, UN human rights staff in 87 countries observed more than 1,300 trials, supported 67,000 survivors of torture, documented tens of thousands of human rights violations, and contributed to the release of more than 4,000 people from arbitrary detention.

They also documented civilian casualties and informed humanitarian responses through risk analysis and early warning in 21 armed conflicts around the world.

For example, the UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission in Ukraine (HRMMU) is the only organization that has maintained a comprehensive record of civilian casualties since Russia first invaded the country in 2014.

“In Sudan, we are providing vital support to survivors of sexual violence and other horrific atrocities, paving the way for justice and accountability,” he said.

Aligning economic policies with human rights

The High Commissioner also stressed that addressing inequalities and respecting economic and social rights are vital to peace and stability.

“Human rights make economies work for everyone, rather than deepening exclusion and breeding instability,” he said.

His office worked with more than 35 governments in 2025, helping them to align all economic policies with human rights. He cited the example of Djibouti, where staff helped conduct a human rights analysis of the health budget, with a focus on people with disabilities.

‘Delivering under strain’

Mr. Türk thanked the 113 funding partners – including governments, multilateral donors and private entities – who contributed to OHCHR’s 2025 budget.

“But at the same time, I have to say – and you know it from our previous encounters – that we are currently in survival mode, we are delivering under strain,” he said.

He outlined several consequences of reduced funding. For example, the Office reduced presence in 17 countries, wiping out programmes critical for endangered, threatened, or marginalised communities such as Indigenous People. Roughly 300 staff out of 2,000 were laid off.

“At a time when truth is being eroded by disinformation and censorship, we had to curtail our support for its guardians – journalists and human rights defenders. Less support for civic space means more surveillance and more repression.”

‘Ambitious, agile and creative’

OHCHR “will need to be even more ambitious, agile, and creative” in 2026, he said.

The UN General Assembly has approved a regular budget of $224.3 million, which is based on assessed contributions from Member States. This amount is 10 per cent lower than in 2025.

Through the 2026 appeal, OHCHR is requesting an additional $400 million in voluntary contributions.

“Historically, human rights account for an extremely small portion of all UN spending. We need to step up support for this low-cost, high-impact work that helps stabilise communities, builds trust in institutions, and supports lasting peace,” said Mr. Türk.

“And we need more unearmarked and timely contributions so we can respond quickly, as human rights cannot wait.”

articles.personality_title: UN launches $400 million appeal to protect human rights worldwide
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The United Nations Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR) works to protect people’s rights in many countries. However, the office has been struggling with less money, making it hard to continue its important work.

**What happened** – On Thursday in Geneva, UN High Commissioner Volker Türk asked for $400 million to support human rights work in 2026. This is on top of the regular UN budget, which is actually smaller than last year. The money will help OHCHR keep tracking human rights violations, supporting survivors, and promoting justice in many places.

**Impact** – Last year, the OHCHR helped 67,000 survivors of torture, watched more than 1,300 trials, and helped release over 4,000 people held unfairly. They also keep detailed records of civilian deaths in conflicts like in Ukraine and support victims of violence in places like Sudan. Without enough funding, many programs that protect vulnerable groups, including Indigenous people and human rights defenders, have been cut back.

**What's next step** – The OHCHR plans to use the new funds to be more flexible and creative in their work. They want more donations that are not tied to specific projects, so they can act quickly when human rights are at risk. The hope is that this funding will help keep peace and fairness in communities around the world.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The UN is urgently seeking $400 million to keep vital human rights protections alive and respond swiftly to crises worldwide.
articles.personality_title_fr: L'ONU lance un appel de 400 millions de dollars pour protéger les droits humains dans le monde
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le Haut-Commissariat des Nations Unies aux droits de l’homme (HCDH) travaille à protéger les droits des personnes dans de nombreux pays, mais manque de financements pour continuer ses actions importantes.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Jeudi à Genève, le Haut-Commissaire Volker Türk a demandé 400 millions de dollars pour soutenir le travail des droits humains en 2026. Cette somme vient s’ajouter au budget régulier de l’ONU, qui est en fait plus faible que l’année dernière. L’argent aidera le HCDH à continuer de surveiller les violations, soutenir les survivants et promouvoir la justice.

**Impact** – L’an dernier, le HCDH a aidé 67 000 survivants de torture, suivi plus de 1 300 procès, et contribué à la libération de plus de 4 000 personnes détenues injustement. Il documente aussi les victimes civiles dans des conflits comme en Ukraine et soutient les victimes de violences au Soudan. Sans financements suffisants, de nombreux programmes pour protéger les groupes vulnérables ont été réduits.

**Prochaines étapes** – Le HCDH prévoit d’utiliser ces nouveaux fonds pour être plus flexible et créatif. Il souhaite recevoir davantage de dons non affectés pour pouvoir agir rapidement quand les droits humains sont menacés. L’objectif est de préserver la paix et la justice dans les communautés du monde entier.

**Une phrase clé** – L’ONU cherche d’urgence 400 millions de dollars pour maintenir la protection des droits humains et répondre rapidement aux crises dans le monde.
articles.personality_title_es: ONU lanza un llamamiento de 400 millones de dólares para proteger los derechos humanos en todo el mundo
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La Oficina del Alto Comisionado de las Naciones Unidas para los Derechos Humanos (ACNUDH) trabaja para proteger los derechos de las personas en muchos países, pero enfrenta falta de fondos para continuar su labor.

**Qué pasó** – El jueves en Ginebra, el Alto Comisionado Volker Türk pidió 400 millones de dólares para apoyar el trabajo de derechos humanos en 2026. Esta cantidad se suma al presupuesto regular de la ONU, que es más bajo que el año pasado. El dinero ayudará a la ACNUDH a seguir documentando violaciones, apoyando a sobrevivientes y promoviendo la justicia.

**Impacto** – El año pasado, la ACNUDH ayudó a 67,000 sobrevivientes de tortura, observó más de 1,300 juicios y contribuyó a liberar a más de 4,000 personas detenidas injustamente. También documenta víctimas civiles en conflictos como el de Ucrania y apoya a víctimas de violencia en Sudán. Sin suficiente financiación, muchos programas para proteger a grupos vulnerables se han reducido.

**Próximo paso** – La ACNUDH planea usar los nuevos fondos para ser más ágil y creativa. Busca más donaciones sin restricciones para poder actuar rápido cuando los derechos humanos estén en peligro. El objetivo es mantener la paz y la justicia en comunidades de todo el mundo.

**Una frase clave** – La ONU busca urgentemente 400 millones de dólares para mantener la protección de los derechos humanos y responder rápido a las crisis globales.

articles.title: UN Police ‘indispensable’ to fulfilling peacekeeping mandates, Security Council hears
articles.summary: The head of UN Peacekeeping on Thursday called for greater support for international police officers deployed to field missions at a time when financial resources are dwindling and multilateralism is waning.
articles.content:
Jean-Pierre Lacroix was speaking in the UN Security Council during the annual briefing by heads of police components of UN peace operations.

“Despite severe constraints, our police personnel continue to serve with dedication, professionalism and courage,” he said.

Tweet URL

“They operate in environments of persistent insecurity, political volatility and growing operational risks.”

Key to peacekeeping

Peace operations depend on UN Police (UNPOL) for community engagement, institutional reform and prevention of criminal and intercommunal violence.

Officers also address challenges that require a policing response, including in environments with high density populations such as displacement camps, among other duties.

“United Nations Police remain a key component of UN peacekeeping and play an indispensable role in fulfilling our mandates,” Mr. Lacroix said.

He stressed that Member States, host countries, uniformed and civilian personnel all share responsibility for ensuring the success of peacekeeping.

This is particularly the case at a time when multilateralism faces unprecedented pressures and peace operations are being asked to do more with less.

Reform and reductions

He noted that the Council meeting was taking place as a comprehensive review of UN peace operations enters its final phase.

It was also held against the backdrop of the UN80 reform initiative and mission contingency planning due to the severe liquidity crisis affecting the entire UN system.

This has led to cost saving measures, including reductions in civilian staff and repatriation of military and police personnel.

Soundcloud

Sustainable financing critical

The peacekeeping chief visited some of the UN’s biggest field missions in recent months and saw how these measures have affected mandate delivery, including protection of civilians.

“Efficiency is necessary. We are committed to finding ways to save. However, this efficiency drive cannot substitute for predictable and sustainable financing,” he said.

“As the Secretary-General has emphasized repeatedly, peacekeeping's ability to fulfill its mandates will be severely compromised without the full and timely payment of assessed contributions from Member States.”

Action for Peacekeeping

Mr. Lacroix also highlighted the renewed Action for Peacekeeping (A4P+) initiative which remains the framework for strengthening the effectiveness, safety, and impact of peace operations.

The seven priority areas include upholding political solutions as the core of sustainable peace, strengthening strategic and operational integration, investing in capabilities and mindsets, and deepening cooperation with host-State police and other law enforcement agencies.

“Across all these priorities, the Women, Peace and Security agenda remains central,” he said.

Although progress has been made in increasing women’s participation and leadership in UNPOL, it “remains fragile, particularly in the context of budget cuts.”

Pledges of support

He recalled that the 2025 Peacekeeping Ministerial Meeting in Berlin demonstrated renewed political commitment to peacekeeping.

The event saw record participation and meaningful pledges, including for specialised roles, rapid deployment and training.

“The pledges are essential to ensuring that UN Police are prepared to respond to emerging threats in areas like transnational organized crime, cyber-enabled crime, climate-related insecurity, and the misuse of new technologies,” he said.

Renewed commitment

Mr. Lacroix concluded by saying his briefing was an opportunity not only to take stock of progress, but to renew collective commitment.

“We must ensure that mandates are matched with adequate resources. We must sustain political unity around peacekeeping,” he said.

“We must protect the institutional gains achieved under A4P+.And we must equip United Nations Police to meet the demands of tomorrow.”

articles.personality_title: UN Police play vital role in peacekeeping amid funding challenges
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The United Nations (UN) runs peacekeeping missions worldwide to help keep peace and protect people in troubled areas. These missions rely on many groups, including UN Police officers, who work to prevent violence and support local communities.

**What happened** – On Thursday, Jean-Pierre Lacroix, head of UN Peacekeeping, spoke to the UN Security Council about the important work of UN Police officers. He explained that despite less money and growing challenges, these officers continue to serve bravely in dangerous and unstable places. He also talked about recent meetings and plans to improve peacekeeping efforts.

**Impact** – UN Police officers are crucial because they help communities stay safe, support local police, and prevent crime and violence. Their work is especially important in crowded areas like refugee camps. However, budget cuts are making it harder to keep enough officers and resources, which could affect the success of peace missions.

**What's next step** – The UN is working on reforms and plans to make peacekeeping more efficient while asking member countries to pay their contributions on time. There are also new efforts to improve training and respond to new problems like cybercrime and climate-related conflicts. The goal is to keep peacekeeping strong and ready for future challenges.

**One-sentence takeaway** – UN Police continue to be essential for peace missions but need steady funding and support to meet growing challenges and protect vulnerable communities worldwide.
articles.personality_title_fr: La police de l’ONU joue un rôle vital dans le maintien de la paix malgré les défis financiers
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les missions de maintien de la paix des Nations Unies (ONU) aident à préserver la paix et à protéger les populations dans les zones de conflit. Ces missions dépendent de plusieurs groupes, dont la police de l’ONU, qui travaille à prévenir la violence et à soutenir les communautés locales.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Jeudi, Jean-Pierre Lacroix, chef du maintien de la paix de l’ONU, s’est adressé au Conseil de sécurité pour souligner le travail important des policiers de l’ONU. Il a expliqué que malgré la baisse des financements et des défis croissants, ces policiers continuent de servir avec courage dans des zones dangereuses et instables. Il a aussi parlé des récents plans pour améliorer les opérations de paix.

**Impact** – La police de l’ONU est essentielle car elle aide à sécuriser les communautés, soutient les forces locales et prévient la criminalité et la violence. Leur travail est particulièrement important dans les zones surpeuplées comme les camps de réfugiés. Cependant, les coupes budgétaires rendent plus difficile le maintien des effectifs et des ressources nécessaires, ce qui pourrait nuire au succès des missions.

**Prochaine étape** – L’ONU travaille à des réformes pour rendre le maintien de la paix plus efficace et demande aux États membres de payer leurs contributions à temps. De nouveaux efforts sont aussi faits pour améliorer la formation et répondre à des problèmes nouveaux comme la cybercriminalité et les conflits liés au climat. L’objectif est de renforcer les missions pour qu’elles soient prêtes aux défis futurs.

**Une phrase clé** – La police de l’ONU reste indispensable aux missions de paix mais a besoin d’un financement stable et d’un soutien constant pour relever les défis croissants et protéger les populations vulnérables dans le monde.
articles.personality_title_es: La policía de la ONU juega un papel vital en el mantenimiento de la paz pese a desafíos financieros
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Las misiones de mantenimiento de la paz de las Naciones Unidas (ONU) ayudan a mantener la paz y proteger a las personas en zonas conflictivas. Estas misiones dependen de varios grupos, incluyendo la policía de la ONU, que trabaja para prevenir la violencia y apoyar a las comunidades locales.

**Qué pasó** – El jueves, Jean-Pierre Lacroix, jefe de Mantenimiento de la Paz de la ONU, habló ante el Consejo de Seguridad sobre el importante trabajo de los policías de la ONU. Explicó que, a pesar de la reducción de fondos y los crecientes desafíos, estos oficiales continúan sirviendo con valentía en lugares peligrosos e inestables. También habló sobre planes recientes para mejorar las operaciones de paz.

**Impacto** – La policía de la ONU es fundamental porque ayuda a mantener seguras a las comunidades, apoya a la policía local y previene la violencia y el crimen. Su trabajo es especialmente importante en áreas densamente pobladas como campamentos de refugiados. Sin embargo, los recortes presupuestarios dificultan mantener suficientes oficiales y recursos, lo que podría afectar el éxito de las misiones.

**Próximo paso** – La ONU está trabajando en reformas para hacer el mantenimiento de la paz más eficiente y pide a los países miembros que paguen sus contribuciones a tiempo. También hay nuevos esfuerzos para mejorar la capacitación y responder a problemas como el cibercrimen y los conflictos relacionados con el clima. El objetivo es mantener las operaciones fuertes y preparadas para los desafíos futuros.

**Una frase clave** – La policía de la ONU sigue siendo esencial para las misiones de paz, pero necesita financiamiento estable y apoyo para enfrentar los crecientes desafíos y proteger a las comunidades vulnerables en todo el mundo.
